Alright. [i]The Crew 2[/i]. Judging from the current all-time high concurrent peak player counts for the game, I'd say a lot of people are aware of this game currently being priced at one dollar (and less in some regions). And a lot of people have bought the game as a result of this stunning deal. Including myself. Just to get it out of the way, if you have something to say about The Crew 1's removal, go to the game forum. I'm not interested in the topic as part of this review. So...  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3329984820  I am confident I would never have bought this game had it not been a buck, and I'm also confident that a lot of people have the same opinion. But since it was a buck, I did in fact buy it, and I'm glad I did. It's hella fun. The gameplay loop of joining events and races, using the cash you earn to buy new vehicles and such, and upgrading your vehicles with loot rewards from events and races, is pretty simple. But it is also effective. As you progress, you will unlock more events and races, and because they are located across the lower 48 States, you get a wide variety of settings for everything. From cities to mountains to forests to lakes to deserts to meteor craters to rain to snow to beaches and on and on, there is a vast array of different types of courses and tracks to enjoy. And there are a wide variety of types of races and events as well. From standard track races to boat races to plane aerobatics to demolition derbies, and so on.  The sheer volume of content is quite impressive. And, the various vehicles, be they cars or trucks or bikes or planes or boats or dune buggies or whatever...they all handle nicely and feel good to drive in. Each of these is upgradeable in many ways, which will increase their performance, handling, speed, and just generally make them function better and better as you progress.  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3329984770  There is a campaign of sorts, where you try to become the lead racer in a few different styles, but it's also easy enough to ignore that in favor of simply racing around, upgrading your vehicles, wandering around your crib, and simply free roaming. And free roaming is a lot of fun in and of itself. Mostly, it's a huge sightseeing trip, where you can also try to beat other player's records with jumps, speed, and so on; that you come across while driving around. And setting some records of your own for other people to beat. And there is a decent photography mini game all across the States where you will take pictures of animals, special vehicles and such to gain more cash and follower.  And gaining followers is really the sub goal that most impacts your playthrough. The number of followers you have determines how popular your racer is, which in turn unlocks new vehicle options and race/event options. Just about everything you do will earn you new followers (and cash).  Also, you can play with other players and even if you're not, you will see them all over the map. At this moment in time (the time of this review being written), no matter where you are, somebody else is nearby. And there are a lot of player created activities as well. Plus, you can co-op with friends if you get bored of solo play. So really, the content just keeps expanding as you explore what the game has to offer.  Visually, the game looks great. It has a 60 FPS cap, which isn't anything to brag about, but somehow, the devs have made the most out of that limitation and made a game that has a never-ending supply of screenshot moments. The audio is also well done. The songs themselves are very cool. The dialogue is basically all "hey bro" Extreme Games fodder, but it's fun and definitely appropriate.  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3330111663  You will need Ubisoft Connect to play this. I don't care at all about that, but you might. And some people are having an issue with the game crashing if they have other non-Steam clients linked to their Ubi account. I have not had that issue personally and have it linked to both PSN and Epic as well, but if you do, you will need to unlink everything except Steam and that will resolve the crashing issue apparently. No idea how or why that is what it is or why it only affects some players. It's been a bug free experience for me though with a 3070 and an i5.  Now, should you also buy the season pass? I personally have no intention of doing so. There's no new content, and I don't care about getting a few extra cars and some swag. But the base game, offering what can easily be hundreds and even thousands of hours of content for one dollar. That is something I can definitely get behind. I can't think of a better deal in gaming at this moment. Now, if you miss or skip this one-dollar promotion they have going on right now, value will be more of...you know..., a [i]your mileage may vary[/i] type thing....  [code]If you found this review helpful and would be interested in supporting my Curator group, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32549618/]Robilar's Reviews[/url], it would be appreciated. Cheers.[/code]

Only frustration, I did not reach Platinum division in the Summit my first week. Being rich in Forza means you can buy and tune a competitive vehicle.  In Crew 2, you buy the base vehicle, but you have to grind for upgrade parts.   FH has classes (B, A, S1, S2).  C2 does not.  All vehicles of same type in C2 have same max tune value. FH no Nitro, C2, Nitro is primary factor. C2, no Auction House nor any way to sell vehicles. C2, leaderboards are more integral, and are a focus of endgame/seasons (Summit). I have over 700 vehicles in FH5. If I had to sum up this game in one word, that word would be "inconsistent". The core racing experience is fun, and the open-world is still a thrill to just fly, race and drift around. However, there are definetly some irks that hold it back:  "That's solid? really?" - you'll find yourself saying this a fair bit, unfortunately. Whilst bus shelters, mailboxes, lampposts and even traffic fold up like they're made of crisps and ping off into space, trees and parked cars are merciless, utterly solid, and occasionally placed exactly where you think you can get that little shortcut.  The AI: Rubberband doesnt even sum the AI up. In fact, it's barely worth trying to drive fast, as they will ALWAYS catch up to you and press their hidden hyperspace buttons the second you overcook a corner. Incredabily frustrating sometimes when you've been in the lead for 95% of the race, then get taken out by a suprise bus on the last corner and finish stone-dead last. Hard mode races up the challenge significantly, but dont be surprised to see the AI disappear over the draw distance within 10 seconds of the start if you havn't grinded out those upgrades for your vehicles.  The Story: If I had to guess, I'd say The Crew 2 was designed to be faaaar more ambitious in it's storytelling. The cutscenes and dialogue you get occasionally before or after a race feel really disjointed, as if there's a big chunk of the story you missed somewhere. One place it particularly confised me was one of the Rival races, where suddenly the mentor who's been urging you on all this time suddenly heel turns so rapidly it's surprising he doesnt do himself an injury, and opens a cutscene by telling your mechanic, Hiro, that you've somehow betrayed him and he wants a race... by doing what he wanted you to and winning races... huh? It just made me confused. Add to this the artsy cutscenes full of pseudo-philosophical commentary that honestly makes zero sense to pop up when they do, and overall the impression that there was a lot of story removed that might have linked these sections together can't be ignored.  There is a lot of good though. The racing is fun, the sensation of speed is excellent, the environments (especially out in the countryside with deserts and the Grand Canyon) are gorgeous and run well, and it really shines when you're just having fun in the open world. Just not in Monster Trucks. Never Monster Trucks. They just... no. horrible.  To sum up, there is a huge amount of potential here. It just needs filling out, and as such in it's present state I can't really recommend it for full price. Maybe after a few updates, it will start to fulfil it's potential. So who made this game again? Oh. Ubisoft. Don't count on the potential being filled then.

Disgusting rubberbanding makes the game so un-enjoyable. Race perfectly and the ai will be right behind you the entire time even if your vehicle is 50 points faster. Of course it's the same the other way around as well, you can eat shit in a ditch and be right behind the leader of the race 10 seconds later because they basically slow down to a crawl if you fall behind, which is incredible because as soon as you pull ahead of them by 5-6 seconds the ai can start to take perfect turns going twice as fast as you like the car is on rails instead of tires. Even worse is the fact that the game punishes you for using your breaks. It's legitimately faster to ride the side rail of a corner and hold the boost than to bother to slow down and take a proper turn.  PSA: I'm honestly super surprised I actually have to explain this here but to everyone commenting about the problem being connection or cpu or w/e else, rubberbanding ai is not a term for lagging. Rubber band AI refers to a feature of artificial intelligence found in racing titles that is designed to prevent players from getting too far ahead of computer-controlled opponents.   Edit: I'm making a sidenote for all the people who are real grumpy about the bad reviews, the base of the game itself is nice. It feels great to freeroam around the map. The physics could have used a bit more tuning but aside from that the cars control as you would expect from a good arcade racer. The problem lies beyond that in the ai. The oponents can decide to hit warpspeed to catch up to you whenever they damn well please. It's not as obvious in disciplines like hypercar racing and the F1 syle discipline, but street races are absolutely atrocious to play. I honestly believe if Ubi went back and fixed some of their problems the game could be great, but as it is, it feels like a big mess. Also, always online game and no PvP for another 5-6 months is a pathetic joke.

I played the game in 4k on a 3080 with an XBOneX Pro controller. All detail was maxed except AA and blur. I do not recommend a keyboard and mouse.  PLEASE NOTE, even though I have left comments on, I am not interested in you telling me that I should put 4000 hours into a game I don't enjoy so I can "git good", and then I would like it. That is a stupid argument. Don't be stupid. Skill is not indicative of enjoyment, and I have better things to do than bash my head on what I personally feel are bad / mediocre games on the off chance I could maybe like them one day. I have a life and don't play games to develop Stockholm syndrome.  Neutrals: - There are 25-minute single races. In an arcade racing game. I hated this. You may not.  Pros: - Most of the time, it ran at 60 FPS. - Large map, but...  Cons: - There is little to see on the map that's interesting. Sometimes the trees change type, and maybe there's more water in an area. - The upgrade system is painfully bad and is essentially a lootbox minus a box. You win a race, you get some random upgrades. You can have, say, LVL 65 in every part but one and it may take you 20 races to get an upgrade for that slot. Yes, you can get RNG'd into having to grind races to upgrade. It's as bad as it sounds. - VERY hard to read tracks when racing. Sometimes you'll just go in the wrong direction because you have no clue where you are intended to go. You essentially have to watch the minimap because watching the race itself is useless as the tracks are signposted more poorly than any other racing game I've played in recent memory. - The AI is tuned incredibly poorly. Either they're WAY ahead of you even though you're driving a better car and the race is half your level, or you're absolutely demolishing them. There is no adjusting this. It is infuriating. - All the cars control like they're racing on butter. Everything slides uncontrollably and really shows off how shoddy the physics are in this game. You will constantly careen into stuff. And speaking of... - Hitting damn near anything brings you to a complete stop. You don't slide past stuff like other arcade racing games when the corner of your car clips a bush, you come to a complete halt. You now have to restart the race because you WILL NOT catch up. Is the race 12 minutes long? Too bad. Now to find that race reset... - The menus are awful. I had to actually Google how to restart a race and quit the game. Thought they'd be in the in-game menus? Hah, you simpleton! You have to hit Y to bring up a special menu that hides in the corner of the screen, but only comes up while driving! Want that menu on a keyboard & mouse? NOPE! Those buttons sometimes show up at the bottom of a different menu where you may have expected them in the first place! Well, sometimes. Only when the option for the buttons feels like appearing. Sometimes it just doesn't. - The characters are astoundingly annoying and are written to speak like a Red Bull commercial. The overtly positive "might as well be saying nothing at all" style garbage non-speaking flows out of everyone's mouth continually. The story is non-existant. If you love chasing "followers" (ugh), then go on Instagram and be vapid there. Even the shell of a life you pretend to have there will be more fun than The Crew 2. - Very odd and frequent framerate drops when physics items interact with each other. This happens often. Adjusting settings did not help. - It looks worse than the original did somehow, and the first was quite an ugly game. - One of the worst game soundtracks I've heard since Gone Home. This low-budget mess of a soundtrack complete with incredibly shrill lady-punk songs. The only good song on the soundtrack is Airbourne - Running Wild, and it's over 10 years old. Yes that's an opinion, and your mileage may vary. - I am an idiot and preordered the Gold Edition because, hey, this is a sequel. It's going to improve on the original in many ways. (Narrator: "It did not.") They didn't listen to a single damn complaint about the original, even though nearly every review both professional and amateur said the same things (Many of which are pointed out in my review here). This makes me madder. You couldn't even be bothered to fix the obvious? Bad form, Ubisoft. - They haven't improved on any of these complaints since launch and instead insist on putting out boring Live Events. This is because Live games make more money (See Destiny). Make no mistake, this is a product, not art and it definitely wants all of your money. - I genuinely tried to like it and power through some of the issues, but I just can't any more. I hate this game. It is one of the worst racing games I have played in recent memory. Even the two most recent Need For Speed games were better, and they were mediocre at the best of times.  UPDATE: Tried it again several years down the road. Holy god there is so much seasonal crap slathered everywhere, and random things to level that they're trying to sell you it was nearly impossible to figure out what to do next. This somehow got even grosser than it was. Oh, and even though the menus have changed, they now make LESS sense due to the sheer amount of layered-on garbage that, AND I still couldn't find a way to quit. I had to Alt + F4.

This game is an improvement over the first one which I defended to be honest. The addition of planes and boats was a great one.  However, I won't give this game a postiive review because Ubisoft intentionally downgraded the game. By that I speak of landmarks. Of all the landmarks they had in The Crew 1, they were all very accurate in terms of shape and relative location. They even had the same ones in the E3 demo. But they decided to remove a lot of them or make them inaccurate for no good reason. If it is a technical reason, it is pure lazyness on the devs part and they jusst used a cheap dirty workaround to fix an issue they had.  I am quite disappointed with the map downgrades. I feel that rather than removing the landmarks, they should have created accurate new ones to further enhance the cities. I will admit the random buildings do look better in this game but the lack of landmarks irritates me.    -In New York the Metlife building, Yankee Stadium, Chrysler Building etc were removed, and the Empire State building was replaced with an inaccurate model. -In Detroit the bridge crossing over to Candida was removed. -In Los Angeles, the City Bank building was altered and is no longer accurate. -The military base north of Chicago was removed. -Downgrades made which decrease the detail to the Hoover Dam  Now Chicago, my home town, got hit hard by the pointless downgrading. About 70 percent of the landmarks were removed. -Sears Tower was removed (Even non Chicago natives will notice this one. Bad decision. Makes me wonder what is wrong with the dev/designer who thought that was a good idea.) -Thompson Center was removed -LaSalle Street Metra was station removed -United Center is gone -Solder Field is gone -The Diamond Building is also gone -The airport was removed (REALLY BAD choice giving the fact the game now has airplanes) -The accurate recreation of Navy Pier was replaced by a bunch of the random filler buildings and props you see all over the map. They are munched together like some kid would make if the game had some kind of map editor which let you place buildings. -The curved building where the river forks was removed. (Forgot the name) -Skyscraper directly south of Sears Tower removed (Also forgot the name) -The Chase Bank building is gone.   What makes me mad is that it is the same map as the first game. You will get a better US road trip experiance in The Crew 1 as the cities featured actually look like the way they are supposed to. They intentionally downgraded it. This game has good gameplay, but screwing up the map makes me belive this game is incomplete and therefore doesn't get a positive review. I'll change my review when Ubisoft restores the content they removed intentionally.  Once Ubisoft corrects their dumb mistakes and gives us the United States road trip experiance that The Crew 1 had, I will change my review.

Crew 2 was controversial at start and ran out of content in 3 months, lost its playerbase in 5 months, Season Pass has been nothing but a scam. About year after launch, big update comes with three new cars (wow!) and MICROTRANSACTIONS (they are only cosmetic and premium currency can be obtained in some ways but donating is much easier). It's Ubisoft, remember, no fun allowed. Even the first Crew had a better potential of holding playerbase with different bodykits to all cars and good crate system even considering the fact that it wasn't at release. Honestly, whole economic system in Crew 2 is messed up, money are really hard to get and best cars cost horribly high, even though $1,4kk car can show similar or even worse performanse than $350k due to "pro settings" and parts which you can switch between cars of the same class and which define the most of car's stats, all you're buying is basically a skin with some advantages (base stats are slightly different nonetheless). Open-world activities are ok, but not profitable, and not all races are profitable as well. There are a lot of them, and developers even add some every now and then, but the main problem is that you are granted with no rewards by completing certain percentage of all races in one class, so there is no point completing all of them - you only get vehicle reward after you beat any story boss, but all you get is mediocre car and trash helicopter which you can't even use in a race. It's easier to find a good relaxing race and farm money there 'till you faint and it seems that it's what most players do. I can't feel a soul in Crew 2. Making matters worse, it's just fucking tedious and grind-based mediocre car game. This vomitous scheme "Grind money to get a better car to grind more money using it". No immersion effect (as in FH4), bad car handling and collision physics, terrible optimisation with painful launches and many, many other bad things. It's year after, not the release date state. When hearing news about Ubisoft making a live-service you should await a death-service.

As I played about 200+ hours in The Crew 1 I have to admit that in The Crew 2 I got bored after 20 hours already.  So let's talk about the things:  1. Price - way too much for this game. Wait for a sale if you REALLY want to play it BADLY. I didn't have fun when playing this game, which shocked me though, because The Crew 1 brought me so much fun. Very disappointing.  2. Map - landmarks are gone, they kinda replaced it with Photo Albums, which is not that bad, however it's kinda annoying (at least for me). Map is huge, but feels totally empty and unused, since they took fast travel to random places away and the map is unlocked, since the beginning, so not much of a grind to be fair. 3. AI - feels really weird sometimes. Sometimes it works normally and sometimes it's just impossible. I had the most issues with Drag Racing where I actually had to watch tutorials to have a chance to beat someone on normal (and no i'm not a total noob, the timing is just so crucial that you need to learn it, which is ridiculous). For beginners the AI is way too OP. If you new and want to have fun you will get frustrated really quickly.  4. Vehicles - probably the biggest plus in this game. There's a wide range of cars, etc., however, with all the classes (boats, planes) it doesn't feel like a REAL racing game anymore. 5. Story - Overall cringe atmosphere, a forced "legal" environment with big parties all over the freaking country. All nice places, which I enjoyed in The Crew 1 just for the nature are now covered with stupid banners and fancy lights, etc. etc. which takes the feeling away. The whole "story" is just a collection of short events, which are apparently huge in the so called TV.  6. Miscellaneous - The followers are replacement of the XP, which is not tragic, but probably annoyed many players who played TC1. The stupid chants after every race or completed skill and music is just annoying.   Overall it's a huge disappointment, there's not much room for grind. I completed all the races for all categories + all skills on 100 % in about 20 hours. I could do the photo albums and buy all vehicles, but the game is just not fun.  If you're new and you want to give it a try wait for a sale. If you're a passioned racing gamer or you played The Crew 1 don't buy this game. That's my OWN OPINION.

[b]What it is:[/b] A massive open-world driving game that boasts the greatest map ever made in its genre but is screaming for more polish in virtually every aspect.  [b]What it does well:[/b] [list] [*]That map - a 1:40 scale recreation of the United States lifted from the original game but updated to accommodate essentially every type of motorized mobility with unparalleled variety [*]A genuinely liberating sense of freedom from a game structured to reward you for doing virtually anything in any vehicle anywhere (except for the PvP) [*]The [i]second[/i]-best game on the planet for relaxation behind Microsoft Flight Simulator - The Crew 2 is at its best not when you're racing but when you're treating it as a giant high-speed walking simulator with no story to speak of [*]An amusingly varied vehicle list that goes from the usual genre staples to things like a biplane, a helicopter, a hovercraft, and more [*]An equally varied array of activity types to engage in - including drift and drag races, aerial stunt challenges, monster truck arenas, demolition derbies, and more [*]A great photo mode held back only by the game's own visual inconsistencies [*]The weekly summits provide a fairly compelling reason to regularly revisit the game to do more than just cruise and chill out [*]Free updates for 29 months and counting [/list]  [b]What it fluffs:[/b] [list] [*]Despite already having hundreds of races in the game, the map still feels underused with loads of unused open spaces and roads [*]No open-world PvP races - a feature that existed in 2007's Test Drive Unlimited [*]No open-world or multiplayer police chases [*]A loot system that seems to be entertaining and somewhat addictive at first, but eventually proves to be generally pointless outside of some top-tier gear sets [*]The environments feel really dated now the second you stop to look, and both draw distance and LOD handling could use an improvement [*]As of late 2020, nights are [i]still[/i] "broken" by design and way too bright due to the developers' inability to properly implement car headlights [*]Strange vehicle physics engine that still doesn't know how to handle collisions convincingly [*]A cheating AI that relies only on stupid levels of rubberbanding to stay competitive [*]Strange UI/UX decisions - chief among them the refusal to save your location upon quitting the game and always forcing you to start each session either at home or an HQ [*]This game has an exceptional number of vehicle types for you to enjoy, but the number of vehicles available in each type is actually pretty underwhelming [*]Horrible story and writing with the only saving grace being how easily they can all be ignored [*]The updates may be free, but content is delivered as a painfully slow drip feed and a lot of the "new" cars are just reskins of the old ones [*]Paywalled seasonal content that doesn't seem to offer any real value [/list]  [b]Technical stuff:[/b] [list] [*]Disappointingly capped at 60fps like its predecessor, but it stays locked at 60fps quite easily too [*]Tons of environmental graphical assets that look like they're from 15 years ago if you stop to look and yet still pass for good looking when you're rolling by at 320km/h [*]Almost complete ultrawide support - HUD and UI are not stretched but remain confined to 16:9 screen space [*]Occasional minor connectivity issues [*]For some reason may become unstable when played with a Bluetooth controller [*]If you have two controllers connected to your PC (e.g. Xbox pad and flight stick), remove one before you start playing because this game idiotically takes input from all devices simultaneously [/list]  [b]Recommendation:[/b] The Crew 2 does do the basics right, but none of those basics can compete with what's on offer in Forza Horizon titles. You're basically here for the map or nothing else, and even that amazing map remains underutilized. The graphics engine appears in need of an overhaul as some serious issues involving pop-in and brightness at night remain unsolved almost two years after launch. It's a good buy for those who loved the first Crew - and its spiritual predecessors, the two Test Drive Unlimited games - and no one else.

a decent casual open world racing game. recommended for people looking for such an experience.  pros - huge open world.entire map of usa slightly scaled down to explore. you can have a big road trip on your own or with friends. vehicle variety - the game is not limited to cars alone but boats planes and bikes as well. lots of different racing disciplines - ranging from street racing to grand prix to moto cross and rally cross. also featured is a cross country hyper car race - goes from east coast to west coast.40 minutes for a single lap race covering the entire width of usa. a great experience in itself. leisurely driving across the grand canyon or other such iconic places has its own novelty. acquiring the cars and upgrading them is satisfying. the set races are well made. snow and rain look nice. graphically the game is good but not upto the standards of other modern racing games like forza  cons -  game is completely arcadish with 0 damage functionality and the physics are very simplistic.its not meant for realistic racing at all. no real pvp features yet (there is an update in the works but no idea how or what it will be)

Let me start this off by saying if you only plan on playing with a controller go for it which is why i'm recommending it ONLY if you're using a controller   If you have a sim rig or even just a basic setup with a wheel you will be extremely disappointed. The force feedback literally makes no sense. You'll be taking a corner and when the rear end slightly slips out from under you the force feedback just decides to fu*k off in a direction that makes no sense. There's an insane amount of options missing that would be in any racing game whether it's an arcade racer or sim with wheel support.   Next issue is the fact that for everyone on PC you are limited to 60 fps with no work around.....like...WHAT!?!? Iv'e literally never played a game on PC that limited my frames to that of a console. What was the thought process behind this decision?   Interface controls moving around the map with a wheel is extremely frustrating but you can get used to it  I have to scroll through every single wheel till I find the ones I want as there are no filter options unless I missed something but come on guys   On the vehicle selection screen there's these flashy light things grazing across the car tabs and is super annoying / makes it hard to see what you're looking at  Some of the cars wheels maximum size still are too small and makes the tires look like they should be on a rally car  Just because we have a sim rig doesn't mean we are limited to sim racers. Sometimes we just want to screw around in an open world environment and zone out which Horizon is great for but that's literally all we have and every NFS title with wheel support is probably even worse than this  In the end if your game is going to have wheel support why even bother having it in the game if you're not gonna do it right?

OK.  I'm going to write this as someone who has been a huge fan of The Crew franchise.  The short answer is, "Yes.  I'd recommend this game."  The longer answer is a little more nuanced and if you'd like to read a few "caveats" from someone who still enjoys the game, mostly......please proceed.  I have played this game since launch.  I owned the "Gold Edition" on PS4 and logged A LOT of hours there.  I then made the switch to PC and, as you can see, I've logged over 200 more hours on here.  There are a lot of positives that any number of other reviews will also bring up.  There are also a lot of negatives, many of which are not immediately apparent.  And here is where I am going to bring these up.  They weren't severe enough for me to not recommend the game, but they were important enough for me to mention.  1.  No cross-platform support or cross-play (not too concerned about cross-play though)  It's one thing to not offer this.  It's another to have very specific rewards for completing certain events and not allow people who earned those rewards to carry them over (or even allow them to use MTX to buy them back on your new platform).  Don't get me wrong, if they asked me to pay money for items I already earned; I'd tell them to get bent.  However, this business model here actively discourages people from buying the game on more than one platform.  Seems stupid.  I have numerous cars earned from PS4 Summit, but because my Uplay account is logged in to a steam version of the game instead of a PS4 version of the game......I can't use them.  2.  It's pitched as "any vehicle, anywhere, any time"  No.  It's not.  Sure, there are plenty of events and lots of different vehicles, but the lion's share of events and vehicles fall in to "street race".  There are more "street race" events than all the other "Street HQ" events combined.  There are more hypercars and street race cars than any other class except for MAYBE Rally Raid and Touring Car.  I don't mind these events/vehicles, but it would be nice to get something else.  It's especially bad for Summit as most "special vehicle rewards" are just another street spec or hypercar spec.  The "Xtreme Series" (one of the more unique aspects of the game) has less than ten events and that's after they added some.  3.  It's "grindy".  Again, clearly I don't mind the grind, but I'd be lying if I said a large majority of my time spent wasn't re-running the same handful of events for cash and parts.  The RNG is hell sometimes and certain vehicle types just get aggravating to get parts for.    For example.  I own full legendary part sets on every single hypercar I own.  I managed to do this in about a week simply re-running the New York hypercar event,  It nets about 300,000 bucks on Ace and yields a BUNCH of legendary parts.  The event is a long cross-country event and takes around 30 min to complete.  Simple enough.  Jump on, run it once or twice, net cash and parts.  But outside hypercars (and one or two street race events) there aren't any events like this for the other specs.  This is ESPECIALLY egregious, because they had stuff like that in the first Crew.  It would be nice if there was a better way of earning legendary sets without relying on Summit or getting to Icon 1000+ to dump a bunch of points in to buffing your loot quality and amount.    4.  "Vanity Parts" and "Premium Currency"  I have an issue with "pay to customize", especially on a game where customizing is a key component to that experience.  It's one thing to pay $5 to have a gold gimp suit or some such crap on Battlefield or CoD.  It's another to have these "pay parts" on a game all about customizing.  It's made worse by the "Season Passes" having a "regular" and a "premium" version and even the premium pass doesn't net you enough Crew Credits to buy an epic vanity part.  You get a couple extra vehicles (probably another street spec or hypercar).  I mostly bring this up because they used to gift Crew Credits a bunch more and just by saving up a bit, you could put them to use in amazing ways and made you WANT to play.  5.  The "Online" Experience.  It's not great.  It's better than a lot I've seen, but it's still pretty bad.  I've had invites from all kinds of people,  almost none that actually want to do events.  You join someone's crew, you screw around on the map until someone gets bored.  Someone joins YOUR crew, they quit as soon as they realize you're starting an event.  Maybe it's time.  Maybe it's the platform.  I can't say for sure.  I CAN say, the social experience WAS better when I was on PS4.  Last but not least, this isn't Forza.  If you're expecting Forza, then buy Forza.  This is more akin to the GOOD Need for Speeds from back in the day (i.e. Most Wanted, Carbon, Underground).  The physics aren't great, but they aren't horrible.  It's mostly just designed to goof off with and have a good time......not recreating what driving a Bugatti is like.  If nothing I said dissuaded you, then give it a try.....and if you see me around, shoot me an invite.  Just don't be afraid of doing something.

The Crew 2 is an open world arcade racing game with the map being the literal entire USA, downscaled to videogame size obviously. Also, i'm hyped for Motorfest even though i'll have to wait another year because Ubisoft, once again, decided to go to Epic Games. They already did come back crawling because Epic didn't work as good as they thought and yet here we are looking at them doing the exact same mistake again missing out on tons of sales because of the selling platform ONLY. Anyways.  I have done every single peace of Content this game has to offer, from races to photo ops but "skills" too and i can tell you i hated almost everything about this game; special hate goes out to every single Boat and Plane activity. I loved playing it, i mean it made me play for 200h+ but i will not ignore how bad of a videogame it actually is  People complain about the Crew 2 but i think its for the wrong reasons; most of the critism is about the grindy aspect of this game and yes they are right it indeed is one of the grindiest racing games ever but to be absolutely honest.. i bought a racing game to win races, if the grind is based on racing then why would i complain? anyways, theres seemingly endless content to be played, most of it feels either the same or really really alike but i really appreciate the cheer amount of content Ivory Tower came up with, set peaces and special events really look and feel cool to go through but it is obvious that most of it were simple instagram filters being put onto your screen to make it feel different even if it mostly isn't.  Graphics are OKAY, it does look outdated compared to even older titles and the antialasing is basically non existent, the backmirrors do not work and your headlights are literally looking like transparent yellow JPGs to make it look like there was light but it actually is no light source at all inside the game engine, the steering wheel barely moves at higher speeds. It definetily has its moments though, it can look pretty and sometimes i had more NFS Underground Vibes than the past 5 Need for Speeds were able to get me but the fact the night time got literally massacred in order to cover up non functioning headlights really bothers me  Heres what i think is important to know before getting into it Anything you do, wether it be menu navigation or real time gameplay, it feels like a mobile game with PC features. Theres so many decisions made in design which simply go all against the user experience to make it as annyoing and uncomfortable as possible and i will have to give you a couple examples to make some sense of what i actually mean:   Every time you finish a race theres an unskippable animation playing telling you that you won, how much XP you got and how much money you earned, it takes almost 10 seconds every single time, right after that you'll see some funny colorfull packages spawning in front of your car so you collect them, these are literally random generated tuning parts which also have (feelingly) hundreds of additional passive effects besides pushing the cars perfomance. Once your inventory is full and you tuned up your car, you gotta dismantle the stuff you don't need and that.. takes way too much time. I could guess that 1/3 of my playtime was dismantling tuning parts only. This entire process is what you get for playing the game. The Tuning is based on RPG NUMBERS and STATS, its no new super duper new engine you build into your car, its literally the same thing now being purple instead of blue (rarity=quality) and the number goes up from 245 to 247.  Other than that the Visual Freedom of your car is astonishingly huge, less for the GT and Hyper Classes but more than ever in street race cars, generally the car selection is almost as impressive as Forzas is.  The AI in your races also base their difficulty on those RPG like "Perfomance Numbers", meaning your car has to have a "220-Stat" to be able to compete in that specific race; this system leads to the AI being either entirely broken or not existent at all. One side of the game makes you want to own as many cars and have as much variety as possible, on the other side theres really obvious differences in cars in same classes. Almost every Muscle Car feels underpowered as hell while other "meta-cars" will have no problems whatsoever; Some cars really do struggle a ton to keep up with the AI, others will make you simply drive the course to the finish line making it a personal time trial.  But wait! theres more! The Crew 2 has an RPG like Skill Tree. It enhanced passive things like "slipstream power", range, effectiveness, it enhanced your nitrous in 7 different ways and makes competing against other lower level people a joke; actually the PVP section of this game is dead since release because of the slipstream mechanic which is absolute BS, you can literally hear your car gaining +100HP as you drive behind your mate. This is a racing game, no MMORPG and most certainly no MOBA, i genuinenly do not understand how one could implement such things into a racing game, making a skill set almost obsolete (of course you still have to know how to drive lol)  Also, there is an ingame real-money shop for you to buy cosmetics, car bundles and battle pass though you can buy the battle pass with ingame money you get from playing  On the plus side though, i really like how easy accessable the multiplayer is. You invite your friend to the party, you choose a race and there you go, no overcomplicated crap needed for this.  I love playing this game but i seriously hate everything that comes with it. In sale for less than 15 bucks, its a good deal for the amount of content you get.

If you've played the first game, then there is some returning stuff that you're already familiar with. The big-ass map, the various racing categories, [b]the grinding[/b], the fact that you'll most likely never own all the vehicles.  Pros: - Planes and boats are fun, the quick vehicle swap function too. - The loot system has been improved (unless you really liked to grind for hours for each car individually). Parts can be exchanged within the category, meaning that you'll get new parts based on the highest parts you own, for any vehicle of the same category. You can buy a brand new, vanilla car, and just install maxxed out parts you already own. - Live Summit events are good.  Mids: - The "you own one car and can outfit it for several categories" system got scrapped. You just own a car for a specific category. Maybe it's also available in a different category, maybe it's not. - The "story" and most characters. At this point, they should just give up the narrative part. Nobody cares, and it's not very interesting. The issue is that it's an arcade game whose very scope makes it hard to explain stuff (you're not going to be surprised by an NFS game being about illegal street racing, but how do you justify the plethora of vehicles available in the Crew? Well... maybe you shouldn't.)  Cons: - Hiro and most in-race announcers and commentary. Gets old reeeaaaal fast. - Just like in the Crew 1, the driving experience can rank from pleasant to extremely frustrating and clunky. - Can take a while to get into a PvP race due to the player population and the waiting system sucks (being able to join "on-call" à la GTAO would be great). - Having to actually go into HQs or your house and walk around to perform actions. Who's got time for that? Why can't I just do it from the menus? - Speaking of the menus... Pointless animations, loading times... And the submenu for the radio that also contains race-related options. That shit is whack.  So, is this a transcending experience? Nah. But it can be fun. Get it if you liked the first one, or if you wanna play with friends.  1) Stay away [u]2) Recommended when on sale or for a specific audience[/u] 3) Recommended 4) Highly recommended 5) This is a must play

After 50 hours, The Crew 2 has left me with a lot of wonderful memories. They aren't filled with the kind of emergent stories you get from exploring an open world and its systems, nor are they moments that involve goofing around with strangers--The Crew 2 is lacking in both those aspects. Instead, my memories are filled with the game's variety of vehicular activities and the wonderfully curated tracks: the unrealistic, the impossible, and the delightful.  It's surprising to see just how much The Crew 2 differs from the original game. There's been a noticeable shift in Ubisoft’s last few open-world titles, one that's moving toward a focus on player-driven progression--large selections of optional activities, non-linear structures, rewards for doing just about anything--and The Crew 2 benefits significantly from this direction. The gritty crime angle from the original game is gone, and instead, The Crew 2 takes reams of pages from the book of Forza Horizon. The game centers on a nationwide festival of motorsports where you, a rookie, are poised to become the next big star. While the setup is conventional, and the focus on social media fame is obnoxious, what it brings to the game is a colorful and upbeat vibe, an impressive variety of different disciplines, and positively ridiculous arcade driving on land, water, and through the air.  Despite the game's focus on real-world branding and mimicry of televised motorsports, The Crew 2's greatest asset is its willingness to be ridiculous. Races in The Crew 2 might involve jumping your street-racing car off skyscrapers, or your powerboat off the Hoover Dam. They might include making high-speed touring cars go head to head through the tight, windy Hollywood Hills, and motocross bikes take jumps across shipping freighters and freeways right before you transform into a prop plane like some kind of extreme-sports mecha. This is a game that will cover Los Angeles in three feet of snow for no logical reason other than icy roads make for more thrilling street races. Abundant nitro boosts, uncomplicated drifting, and generous rubber-banding also help keep the act of driving exciting when things are relatively tame.  As a game with an open world, races and challenges can naturally be found and initiated when you stumble across them at particular points on the map. However, playing The Crew 2 with open-world exploration as your primary means of moving from activity to activity reveals the game's major downfall: it's too big, and all the activities and interesting locations are too spread out. The game hides a number of boxes with vehicle components across the map, which you can hunt for using a proximity tracker, but even these feel too few and far between.  But with that in mind, The Crew 2 thankfully makes it easy to cut your commute down via player-friendly shortcuts. The game has an option to view all 120+ primary activities and countless more skill challenges (featuring things like escapes, slaloms, and a rewarding photo mode) in a categorized, list-style view, with the option to not just set a waypoint to them, but instantly start them no matter where you are in the world, at no cost. The loading times in The Crew 2 are impressively brief all around, so if you want to, you can churn through races and challenges back-to-back to very quickly and efficiently rack up progression points, earn cash, and set leaderboard positions from the moment you start.  It's an option that's both convenient and gives the impression that the game is conscious of your time. Likewise, any activity can be restarted or aborted in seconds if you're having a bad run, and there's a quick back-on-track feature that can be used any time. When you're not in an event you can switch to any vehicle you own immediately, without penalty, and without having to go anywhere. That's on top of being able to assign a favorite ground vehicle, boat, and plane to your right analog stick to allow for instantaneous switching during free-roam exploration, which provides its own kind of fun, for example, flying into the stratosphere with your plane before switching to a boat and careening back to Earth. Any vehicle that's available for sale is also graciously available for you to test drive on a moment's notice.  The variety of different vehicular disciplines in The Crew 2 is downright impressive--each of the 14 styles is tangibly unique from one another. Every time I started to get fatigued with one method of competition, I could quickly jump to another that had a completely different feel. Each is housed within one of four "Families" which you're free to move between to perpetuate your overall progress: Street (street racing, drifting, drag racing, long-distance hypercar racing), Offroad (cross-country rally raid, motocross, loose-surface rallycross), Freestyle (plane aerobatics, jet sprint boating, monster trucking), and Pro (power boating, air racing, touring cars, and grand prix).  While the execution of The Crew 2's disciplines might not wholly satisfy purists of any one given style, it does a great job of making each feel accessible, fun, and unique. I'm usually too intimidated by grand prix racing to give it a shot in other games, and I would never have even considered the idea of playing a power boating game. But, the Crew 2 encourages you to try a little bit of everything, and it's easy thanks to the game's approachable arcade-style mechanics, as well as the prospects of seeing more beautiful and ludicrous tracks.  And whether you're driving, boating, or flying across The Crew 2's America, it's a mostly beautiful journey. The game's natural environments, particularly bodies of water and the sky, look fantastic, as do weather effects like snow and rain. All are enhanced to breathtaking heights by the superb lighting, though the continuous day/night and weather cycle can be an occasional inconvenience during some events--whether it be afternoon sun in your eyes, snow obscuring track obstacles, or having to fly through a tight canyon in complete darkness. Where the visuals visibly falter are in dense urban areas. You likely won't notice buildings when you're zooming past them at 200km/h, but any slower and you can't help but notice how plain they are, especially in broad daylight with clear skies. Character models, on the other hand, always look incredibly basic, no matter the situation.  The game's RPG-style vehicle upgrade system returns from the original game, though it still doesn't feel particularly meaningful. You'll receive loot after every race in various stages of rarity (common, uncommon, rare, epic), and each corresponds to a particular vehicle part and has its own power number, which contributes to your vehicle's overall power number. There is some small benefit to this system--all vehicles of a particular class, despite having different power levels in their stock configuration, will max out at the same number, meaning you can stick with your favorite car all the way up to and through the endgame.  I'm annoyed by the game's lack of public interaction and meaningless gear system, but I'll fondly recall both the tension of flinging sprint boats back and forth through the narrow, artificial canals of The Venetian in Las Vegas, and the easygoing satisfaction of an hour-long hypercar race from New York to San Francisco, where I listened to a podcast and enjoyed the rolling scenery. Despite its shortcomings, The Crew 2 still displays admirable strengths, which lie in its player-friendly features, freedom of movement, and its willingness to bend the rules in order to make things exciting and varied for an accessible, American-themed thrillride.

✓ 150 Hours ✓ Completed 100% of the game content ✓ Completed 100% of the achievements  Here is a rundown of Pros and Cons, with explanations, along with a score breakdown and final conclusion.  Pros:      • Captivating           -With each race comes different tracks, different skips, and different means of completing. With a percentage displaying the completion of a discipline (style of race) and an online competitive track time it’s very easy to get stuck into this game. Though a track can be completed it can always be done better, this factor is what drives the racers to become faster and better.      • Updated Often      • Good portrayal           -The game does an accurate portrayal of each discipline. Whether one loves Street Racing, Off-Roading, Free-Styling, or Pro-Racing, The Crew 2 provides just what one’d believe this discipline would be like.      • Tuning           -With tuning, and even pro-tuning, each vehicle may be adjusted to preferred likings. Tuning can make or break, quite literally, a vehicle. These tuning options can add Top Speed, Power, 0-60, Quarter Mile, and more.       • Great for a completionist           -The Crew 2 is not easy to complete, but it is easy to manage and observe the progress. Each discipline comes with a percentage of completion. In game, there is also an option to pin desired missions to track progress real time.   Cons:      • Poor story           -There is little to no story on this game. Your objective is to simply “become the champion”, which is done by just racing. The story focuses on being “follower famous” which is well, I guess a good portrayal of 2018.      • Awful commentary           -The commentary is quite laughable. Some lines do not make sense to even be mentioned, while others are just repeated.      • Inconsistency           -It’s somewhat of a hit or miss, funny pun, on which items are moveable. Some large trees are destructible while other small tables are not.      • Iffy graphics           -At times the graphics are phenomenal, at other times it’s feels like I’m back in 2007. The photo editor is very solid, but the in-game scenery is lacking.      • Poor reward           -Even when completing disciplines, there is hardly any reward. The only rewarding system is given after playing many hours and becoming the status of “Icon”.  -Scoring- Content 7/10 Graphics 5/10 Story Line 3/10 Score, 15/30, 5/10, 50%  -Conclusion- I purchased a racing game and I believe that’s what I got. Though the game is lacking in commentary and story, that’s not what I personally purchased it for. I purchased it to race, which is what this game excels at. The Crew 2 is a very entertaining racing game that will certainly give hours of enjoyment (as long as you don’t care about story line and such).

Well well well!  It's 6 months now since i bought this one and i decided after 111 hours of gameplay to review it.  [h1]First the alternative titles i would give this game.[/h1]  Ford Focus hating simulator  Epic Car Wallpaper maker  Bugatti porn  The faster hatchbacks  The Crew 2 sponsored by Ford, Bugatti, Dodge and Chevrolet.  [h1] Gameplay [/h1]  The gameplay itself is really good, the tutorial (well it's a Ubisoft game there isn't much to expect) isn't well thought of in my opinion.  You start of with a vehicle the game gives you to finish your first mission.  After that you've been given a (rather small) selections of vehicles/cars for free.  The further you progress into the game the more options and challenges as well as vehicles get unlocked.  For the cars for example Ubisoft decided to help you progress by giving you a free Aston Martin Vanquish (which honestly helps a lot).  The game itself offers you various types of challenges and gamemodes so you never get bored.  When it comes to missions, i sadly have to mention that the npcs even on the higher difficulty seem to struggle sometimes. Weather conditions while in a mission are nice but could cost you your lead since it looks like the npcs don't struggle with it as you do.  More to that later on.  [h1] Design [/h1]  Even on a lower setting the design and graffics are good enough for amazing screenshots.  The cars are well detailed like the real life ones, you have a very simplified map and speedometer and the menus aren't in any way confusing.  The settings are nicely ordered which is consumer friendly.  [h1] The good things [/h1]  Amazing graphics with great detailing.  Good and constructive gameplay.  A good variety of vehicles to choose from.  A photo mode with a great variety of settings to make your perfect screenshots.  A huge and well detailed map of the US  A lot of missions and challenges to choose from.  [h1] The bad/salty things [/h1]  As stated earlier, weather conditions with bad traffic could easily ruin your race.  The Navigation responds very slow and bugged since the last update  The developers seem to gotten sponsored by the car manufactorers mentioned earlier because of the sheer amount of cars of each brand that are in the game.  Some car manufactorers that have produced amazing cars e.g. Toyota, Lancia, Skoda are completely left out which is sad to be honest.  The tutorial isn't really helpful when you haven't played the game before.  [h1] The confusing things [/h1]  For example, the aero of all the cars (even those with a huge rear spoiler) isn't considered even though the game tries to be really realistic  AWD(All-wheel-drive)-Cars like the BMW M8 behave like RWD(Rear-wheel-drive)-Cars, but FWD(Front-wheel-drive)-Cars behave like RWD-Cars with more traction  Some stats of the cars are confusing: VW Golf GTI 0 - 100 km/h   2.4 seconds HP: 550                                                               Bugatti Veyron 0 - 100km/h 2.6 seconds HP: about 1670  The weight of the cars aren't mentioned and most likely not even considered in the game.  So how could your regular Golf GTI with FWD be faster from 0 - 100km/h than a hypercar that costs irl like 3.5 million Euros?  [h1] My verdict [/h1]  It is a great game with a few twists but you can enjoy it in any way you like since it's an open-world game with many options and way to play it.  Do you like to just casually drive around?  You can just do it.  Or crash into the statue of liberty with a plane for fun?  Yeah go on.  The game won't force you to play it in a specific way.  So in short i recommend it if you like cars like i do.  Short notice: Please do not take this review all so seriously since it's my honest opinion on it.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]  [h2]The Crew 2 Review[/h2]  [table] [th][h2]Factors[/h2][/th] [th][h2]Rating[/h2][/th] [th][h2]Description[/h2][/th] [tr] [td]🎮Gameplay[/td] [td]8[/td] [td]So many vehicle choices that you will love atleast 1-2. [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]🎰Re-playability[/td] [td]9[/td] [td]Easy to repeat and pretty much endless. [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]💲Price[/td] [td]6-9[/td] [td]6 on base price and 9 on sale. [/td] [/tr] [/table]  [i] My impression of the game kept on changing at each progressing 5 hours interval. This review was framed after investing 30+ hours into the game and concluding the final rivalry races. The initial hours were so repulsive and full of meh impressions. But once you get a hold of a particular vehicle type and its handling, it’s all fun and excitement.[/i]  [h1][b] 📝Story/Plot:[/b][/h1] Just a generic plot setup to give your grind some motive and goal. A rookie entering the world of racing and guess what, some organizers see his potential and gave him a chance without even seeing him race beforehand. Just be #1 all around the events and conclude your journey after beating the top dogs who were the organizers too.  [h1][b]🎮Gameplay:[/b][/h1] [b]Initial impression-[/b] Imagine a hot girl with no personality. That’s the first 5-minute impression of The Crew 2. Starting off with high budget cinematics and performing short lap segment races while shifting to a new vehicle again and again. Sounds cool right? Wait until you see the whole f*cking world curve like in the movie Inception and Doctor Strange. At this point, my jaw was indisputably touching the ground. But just after completing a normal event race, it hit me with gloom and awkwardness. All that cinematic brag of “Speed is Life” and bla bla comes down to a slow race with the road looking like a low texture road. Like WTF?  [b]Mechanics/Controllability-[/b] I know it’s not a real sim racing game, nor advertised as a pure arcade. It’s unique on its own. But I feel like not giving it a category works as a bypass for some faulty mechanics. Cars feel slightly slow and weigh a ton on the controller. The purpose of a racing game is to acknowledge the speed atmosphere, which was only endured with top cars. Cars are not at all hard to control, rather easy and amusing. It’s the damn AI that makes all the races so tryhard. You are in lead for 97% of the race and suddenly an AI got a God’s hand and achieved supersonic speed. If you are thinking of bumping into them and play dirty, well have fun bumping a rubber band. All these aspects are blades of the same sword. AI feels difficult- what a tryhard game/Thank God it’s not cheap easy. Perspective matters here. I am not against it. Surely it’s sometimes annoying, but it iz what it iz.   It’s easy to understand how ground vehicles operate, steer, brake, drift, boost. But you are not familiar with aeroplane controls. Despite that, the first intro race makes you race an aeroplane. Instead of crossing checkpoints with my plane, I was crashing into enormous buildings and respawning. A terrible scenario that gets fixed in later event races where they teach you all aeroplane controls bit by bit.  [b]Open World-[/b] Take on the American motorsports scene as you explore across the entire USA. Being able to drive different vehicles like cars, bikes, boats and planes in the same open-world means not only you are free to drift your car on street roads, tread speedboat through the waterways but fly high across the sky too. Befitting pillars for the open-world statement. Now we know there are no restrictions, but what about interactables? Unfortunately, that’s a guessing game. Oh, I have a sharp turn incoming and I have to drift? Let’s do this then. You are halfway in your drift airmailing all those bus shelters, mailboxes, lampposts in space, but suddenly you see a bench in between. That’s your stoppage. These randomly placed objects like benches or parked cars don’t follow Newton’s Law. They just wanna remain stationary no matter how hard you hit them. Trust me, these little objects ruined a lot of my lap times.  [b]Variety-[/b] You can use the astonishing top-notch live map, which single-handedly increases the game score by 2. Like how they even made it render the entire game in a 3D model just by a single click. Moving forward, the complete map contains various types of events/races you can take part in. Just for clarification, there are not AI vs races only. You can take part in a race against time, drifting, freestyling and a lot of car chases too. As I said, you are buying a complete package of the racing genre with multiple vehicle types. But there seems to be a hollow part of the story. During cinematics, you can easily see the top-quality work put together and the exciting race descriptions they narrate. But in reality, you won’t find those races in action. One cinematic had an image of a monster truck jumping out of a plane with a parachute, but there’s nothing present like that. They escalated the expectations through cinematic dialogues but disappointed us in the end. It’s not completely devastating as the default variety is already more than enough.  [b]PvP/Grinding-[/b] Sadly, you can’t run away from the “Look, there’s a level 1 guy with lvl99 car” scenario. It’s Ubisoft, which means expect a lot of transactions. Buy bundles, buy a season pass (Motorpass), or add in-game currency and get any high-speed car you want, but if you don’t wanna spend a penny, good luck grinding your a*s out. Be a part of a crew and evade the boredom of grinding alone.  [h1][b]📷Graphics:[/b][/h1] Enjoy a pizza full of delicious and uplifting toppings added on a half-cooked bread base. Now all your bites will have a random taste. Some will please your tastebuds, and some will taste like cardboard. The object detailing in the open world is great, but their textures, Oh Lord. Never expected to witness those low texture brick buildings from a 2018 game. Like, come on; all the vehicles, roadside objects, even dirt tracks look so good. Then why the buildings and gravel roads look like a dusty mirror. To avoid these bad graphic races, I played air and water races the most.  [h1][b]📝Main Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]  [b]Pros-[/b] [list]     [*]Big Open-world.     [*]Character and vehicle customization.     [*]Good chunk of playable time.      [*]Multiple vehicle types.     [*]Varied races and challenges.     [*]Offline or Online races. [/list]  [b]Cons-[/b] [list]     [*]Grind vs PayToWin is real.     [*]Semi cooked graphics.     [*]Annoying indestructible objects.     [*]No dynamic weather in the open world. [/list]  [h1][b]🏷️Tips to new players:[/b][/h1] Keep in mind, you can drift your plane. Without this, you are going to kiss the land whenever you take a flight. Don’t start PvP races until you reach at least the Famous rank. There are no restrictions on which racetrack to follow. So cut the track however you want. The first one to cross the checkpoint is the winner. Change resolution to borderless. Otherwise, whenever you will Alt+Tab, the game will start re-syncing, which wastes 4-10 seconds of your life every time.  [h1][b]😇Honest Rating:[/b][/h1] If you are looking for that NFS arcade or real sim racing like Assetto Corsa and Project Cars, then just buy them instead. It’s nowhere perfect or overly marvellous. But I can assure you, if you invest enough hours into the game, you will adore it even as toxic relation. Only buy on big sale!  Rating: 8/10 Best world bending I ever saw.

The Crew 2 is one of my all-time favorite racing games, mostly because of all the freedom the player has. I'm not like the average car fan, in racing games I usually like to see how crazy I can make a car look instead of customizing it as if it was a real world vehicle, and the crew 2 is the perfect game for players like me. The customization is amazing, there are dozens and dozens of different parts for each of the nearing 400 vehicles, including a livery creating system to make and share skins with the community. The Crew 2 also has a big variety of vehicles, including my favorite, the DMC DeLorean (though I hope sometime soon they'll add tesla vehicles to the game!). The map is also extremely large, with amazing graphics, especially lighting. The tracks/courses are fun and creative, although some can be annoying at times. Overall, I give The Crew 2 5 stars, and I would recommend the game to any racing fan.

5/10 - Lots to like, but lots to hate. Could have been so much more. Full review below:  = Intro =  Sometimes, I'm in the mood for a racer. I fondly remember the days of NFSU 2, Gran Turismo on the PS and Most Wanted, games that not only lasted me weeks, but gave me new bands to listen to and endless replay value. Had this on my 'to play' list so got around to it. Enjoyed Forza, but it felt a bit flat and I wanted something with a bit more progression.  = Gameplay =  This is a racing game. Vrooom, cars go fast. But it's also a watersports game. And an offroad game. And a rally game. And a flying stunts game. And a flying racer game. And another dozen types of racing/stunt game rolled into one. Oh and also a loot game. You can see the problem immediately.  That said, man - this game does try. And sometimes gets it right. The water racing is immensely fun. Rally racing is great. Motorcross is mostly a blast. The absolute apex of the game for me are the lengthy 'runs' - massive races between cities, that lead you through towns, cities, mountains, forests etc. Glorious.  The weakest part of the game for me has to be the street racing, which isn't the nice, varied, speedy tracks you are likely expecting, but rather boxy, twisty monstrosities filled with right-angle turns. Right off the bat, these were frustrating as heck and some of the later ones will make you want to eat a kitten.  This has to do with the fact that a lot of cars handle like shopping carts and the more expensive ones handle like shopping carts with a jet booster. This game works best with long, open tracks, which sadly are lacking in a lot of styles.  Beyond this, every 'discipline' has it's own set of vehicles and loot. Welcome to the grind overdrive. And this is made worse by the fact that the sheer number of event types means that many only get a handful of races, total.  However the kicker is the AI. It...cheats. Rubberbanding is utterly crazy, especially when you start doing higher difficulty races - but unlike other games, it's only applied to give the AI an advantage. If you fail to drive perfectly on some tracks, the AI will soar past you instantly. Or it may just randomly do that anyway.  However once the AI is ahead, it just keeps on going. This is especially evident in the set-vehicle races where you and the AI have (allegedly) the same vehicles and specs. However, on Ace, you can enjoy the sight of the AI flying into the distance right from the get go, waving and flipping the bird.  This leads to a lot of styles being not only about driving prowess but luck, and finding ways to break the game. Weird, unmarked shortcuts, odd physics and the like. Sigh.  All of that said though, I don't hate this game. When it works, it works like gangbusters. Maybe if they had removed the boring flying stuff and produced double the races for existing styles, this could have been a winner.  = Graphics and Audio =  Visually, this game is a mixed bag. Water is lovely. Weather is beautiful. Lighting can be stunning. But textures are meh and ...wow, do cities look awful. Especially at daytime. Framerates are perfect.  Audio, rather than the mix of metal, rock, punk, rap and EDM you may be expecting is instead a small collection of the blandest EDM known to man.   = Style =  As I've said - too cluttered, too thinly spread.  And the interface/design is a nightmare. Let's say you do a race a few times, restarting immediately after you finish. Your loot goes to the mailbox. You then need to leave the race (loading time), go to a racing base (loading time), walk around, get the mail, exit the base (loading time), go to your home (loading time), walk up to your vehicle stand, change your vehicle (loading time) and then upgrade it.  Welcome to busywork.  But the absolute worst thing for me was discovering, after returning to the game after a long period, that there was no way to reset progress, whatsoever. Meaning if you experiment early and foul things up, there is no way to ever remedy it.  = Value =  To be fair, there is a lot here for the price, especially if you get this game on it's frequent, really good specials.  There are microtransactions, but most of the stuff can be earned in-game. However there is also stuff that can't. And I'm sick of microtransactions in AAA priced games.  = Overall =  + Many events are insanely fun + Original and well implemented loot system + 'Run' races are just awesome  - Impossible to ever reset progress/start a new game - Insanely cheaty AI - Frustrating street racing - Awful interface - Open world feels meaningless - Spread way too thin - Ubisoft style microtransactions  At the end of the day, this is a game I really want to like. With a bit more focus, less insane design decisions and some better/more interesting tracks, this could have been amazing. As it is...it's both enjoyable enough to keep me playing and flawed enough to make this hard to recommend.
