Many people say that this game is bad, assuming that it is because of the horrible graphics you will always notice. Personally, this is one of the games that I would recommend to give some time to spend on because it is fun and the player has freedom to cruise around and do numerous activities whether you play by yourself or with a built crew.  With the ability to switch to another vehicle whether air or water while driving, you get to realize that there are so many things that this game offers. For me, this is an awesome game, though the sole issue I have with this game is that it is only playable ONLINE. I wish there is a feature where in you can drive around and participate in races even without the online feature or just disabled online mode. In addition to the free-roaming, there are races that provide the player a huge drop of cash and with the ability to increase the number of drop of car parts and money by progressing your ICON stats, you are guaranteed wealthy enough to purchase numerous vehicles of different disciplines that are so many that I am speechless of this game and how amazing it is.  To conclude. The Crew 2 is fun. Surely some will say the graphic renditions, especially buildings and environments have awful sight to it, but still, with all honesty, this is a fun game to play. If you purchased the Gold Edition, you will receive free, if I am not mistaken, 22 vehicles for free and few exclusive vehicles that you can get for free.

This game has received a lot of hate. Personally, I believe a lot of the hate it undeserved, but they can make some good points.  Starting with the pros: - Vehicle variety and detail. This game has over 300 different vehicles, and personally I believe the detail on the vehicles is out standing, even things as small as bolts for some extended fenders:   10/10  - Vehicle Customisation. Almost all of the vehicles have a wide range of changeable parts. There are many options to choose from in an easy to navigate menu, as well as bonus items that can be rewarded from playing the game by doing daily missions giving you a currency to buy special items such as under glow, custom wheels, tire smoke and more.         9/10  - The Map Size. The map size is where this game stands out above all. In a fast car (280Mph top speed+) with good driving it took me over an hour to travel from the southeast tip to the north west tip. In this map you will find several cities and other land marks along the way, also encountering the occasional player along your journey. The details in the cities are spectacular and the amount of places to go are countless.     10/10  - Multiplayer. The game puts you into a public lobby filled with usually around 3 to 8 other players, communicating with a custom chat menu which prevents and toxicity or bullying. When you want to play alone you can but on the other hand if you are looking to go on a road trip with a friend or do some races with a pal this game has made an easy system for you to do so.       8/10  - Race Variety. Currently in the game there and 16 different Motorsports events to choose from:       -Street Race, Drift, Drag race, Hyper car       -Motor cross, Hovercraft, Rally cross ( off-road ), Rally raid       -Freestyle ( Stunt planes), jet sprint ( Small boat racing ), demo derby, Monster truck       -Touring car, F1, Boat racing, Air race Along with these you get different skill based activities like Speed-traps and escapes ( furthest distance in a period of time ) as well as Photo ops of landmarks or player scenarios.          10/10  - The Summit. Every week, there is a series of events that you can do competing against other players in order to win prices such as followers, parts or occasionally, cars. This feature gives a deep purpose to this game, and for me a feeling like i need and want to come back to do those races and get those prizes. 10/10  Smaller mentions: -Unlimited garage space -Customisable car settings and parts -As you level up, you will receive rewards at certain milestones ( Cars planes boats etc )   And now the Cons:  -Graphics. This game can look beautiful, however a lot of the places feel empty or dull, like they need something extra. Also, the shading was poorly made, with a lot of colours looking flat. Like I said, certain places look fantastic and are very photogenic, however the textures aren't HD and could have more colour. With a simple graphics remake this game could easily be level with GTA V or FH4.     3.5/10  -Sound. Some of the car sounds are well executed, but for the most part they seem dull and like they could be more intense. The vehicles that do sound good are incredible, however a lot of cars that seem powerful get underwhelmed by the sounds coming from the engine.  4/10  -Weather. Now when i say weather I need to make it VERY clear i mean the weather changing, not the visuals. In my opinion, the rain in this game falls just short of GTA V rain puddles in the city at night, but with this game you can be in sunny weather, you go into settings to maybe turn your sound down a little and when you are out of the menu, boom: Thick snow. Even when it changes visibly to the player, it is too fast and too frequent. 5/10  -The Voices. Oh my lord turn off voices and turn on subtitles because the majority of the voices in this game are infuriating and get super annoying super quick.     1.5/10  -The prices. The vehicle prices can be realistic and occasionally generous, with a Buggati Chiron costing 2.4 million, but then when you venture over to the low end of the spectrum like bikes, you start to see prices like 500 grand for a sports bike. It isn't accurate. Another thing to mention is the grind for money. The money received after a race needs to increase, as grinding mindlessly for 3 hours in order to save up 2.4 million like I have done gets quite frustrating, and whilst it normally pays off, the pain you feel inside when you know the only way to get yourself that money you need for your next car is going to take 100 races of the same race is discomforting and off-putting.  Important note: i see a lot of people talking about rubber banding and i need to say i have never experienced this. I often finish races 10-30 seconds ahead when i use my super fast vehicles, and on other races like the 40 minute race it is often minutes ahead. If there was rubber banding, how could the times they are behind me be so large?  To summarise, I am saying this game is worth it, but keep it in your wishlist until it is on a sale to make up for the cons you may experience in this game.  Peace.    Side note to any active players: Anyone down to do some races together? DM me.

The Crew 2, a game where you can switch from driving a hypercar to piloting a plane faster than you can say "Did I just clip that skyscraper?"  The game’s map is a condensed version of the USA, which means you can drive from New York to Los Angeles in about 30 minutes. Take that, real-world traffic!  Switching between vehicles is as simple as pressing a button. One moment you're cruising down the streets of Miami, and the next, you're free-falling from the sky because you accidentally transformed into a boat mid-air. Pro tip: boats don't fly.  The variety of races is vast, and so are the number of trees I've crashed into while attempting to pull off that "totally planned" drift. And let's not forget the photo mode challenges. Nothing says "professional photographer" like trying to snap a pic of a flamingo while barrel-rolling in a jet.  In conclusion, the game is pretty fun, sure the handling physics aren't anything like NFS of Forza, but the game has its charms.

[h1] Stop Destroying Videogames [/h1]  [b]  European Citizens' Initiative :  Video games have grown into an industry with billions of customers worth hundreds of billions of euros. During this time, a specific business practice in the industry has been slowly emerging that is not only an assault on basic consumer rights but is destroying the medium itself.  An increasing number of publishers are selling video games that are required to connect through the internet to the game publisher, or "phone home" to function. While this is not a problem in itself, when support ends for these types of games, very often publishers simply sever the connection necessary for the game to function, proceed to destroy all working copies of the game, and implement extensive measures to prevent the customer from repairing the game in any way.  This practice is effectively robbing customers of their purchases and makes restoration impossible. Besides being an affront on consumer rights, video games themselves are unique creative works. Like film, or music, one cannot be simply substituted with another. By destroying them, it represents a creative loss for everyone involved and erases history in ways not possible in other mediums.  Existing laws and consumer agencies are ill-prepared to protect customers against this practice. The ability for a company to destroy an item it has already sold to the customer long after the fact is not something that normally occurs in other industries. With license agreements required to simply run the game, many existing consumer protections are circumvented. This practice challenges the concept of ownership itself, where the customer is left with nothing after "buying" a game.     We wish to invoke Article 17 §1 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union [EUR-Lex - 12012P/TXT - EN - EUR-Lex (europa.eu)] – “No one may be deprived of his or her possessions, except in the public interest and in the cases and under the conditions provided for by law, subject to fair compensation being paid in good time for their loss.” – This practice deprives European citizens of their property by making it so that they lose access to their product an indeterminate/arbitrary amount of time after the point of sale. We wish to see this remedied, at the core of this Initiative.   We also invoke Title XV of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU)[EUR-Lex - 12012E/TXT - EN - EUR-Lex (europa.eu)] and the following TFEU Articles as our justification for and the Union’s imperative to respond to this initiative:  Article 169 – Per §1, the EU has an obligation “to promote the interests of consumers and to ensure a high level of consumer protection…to protecting the health, safety and economic interests of consumers”. We believe this practice infringes upon or requires correction to be commensurate with the EU’s obligation. The actions taken in response to this initiative must supersede any end user license agreements associated with videogames.    Article 12 – “Consumer protection requirements shall be taken into account in defining and implementing other Union policies and activities.” Given that this practice extends across Member States and beyond the EU, the Union’s actions regarding this practice ought to keep consumer protection in mind. The actions taken in response to this initiative must supersede any end user license agreements associated with video games.  Article 114, §3 – “The Commission, in its proposals envisaged in paragraph 1 concerning health, safety, environmental protection and consumer protection, will take as a base a high level of protection… Within their respective powers, the European Parliament and the Council will also seek to achieve this objective” This practice undermines the high level of consumer protection that the Commission, the European Parliament, and the Council takes as the basis of law in the Union, and their objectives of establishing and maintaining the functioning of an internal market as described in §1 of this Article, and Article 26 TFEU.[/b]  [h1] THE CREW 2 IS NEXT! SIGN THE PETITION! [/h1]

Easily one of the best arcade racing games out there. Most of the critics are by the people who either judged the game by playing just a couple of hours or those comparing it with other racing/driving games. Here's my take on its pros and cons:  PROS:  1. Map: Insanely huge map of the USA. Has almost all the visiting sites you can think of. It'd take you half an hour to drive from NY to San Francisco. You can never get bored of the map, period.  2. Car collection: Huge car collection from all the popular makes. They keep adding more every week and with every new update. Same with boats, planes, etc. You can actually buy like 98% of the cars without paying actual money. You might need some grinding though. 'New York' or the 'Uber dam' are good events to grind.  3. Car customization: You can customize almost everything from car color to tires, rims, wings, body kits, smokes, nitros, windows, even the underglows. There's also a good, active community that keeps adding custom liveries (skins/vinyls) which you can apply to your cars directly. And of course, there's a decent liverly editor too.  4. Race tracks: Challenging and fun race tracks. Some even have good shortcuts which you can master by driving repeatedly. You may try to break some of the world records.  5. Diversity: Various disciplines to choose from. You ever get bored from the street races, you can do boat race, jet race, air race, motorbike race, monster trucks, you name it. Although the game has good diversity, it's biased towards street races due to the number of events available in it compared to other disciplines. But then, if you're a street racing fan, that's what you want.  6. Regular content update: Really impressed with the 'Live Summit' weekly events with unique themes. You compete with other players to get the prizes. Prizes being special edition cars, tires, car parts, nitros, followers, etc.  CONS:  1. Graphics: Being a 2018 game, the graphics could've been better. You can't expect amazing graphics for such a giant map but the textures and reflections could still be better (as they're reused a lot). The lightings/weather system is good during the day with bright sunlight but it looks like a water painting when cloudy or rainy. The nights are okay at best.  2. Unbalanced AI: The AI in the game is somewhat unbalanced. I mean you can easily win street races or hypercars in Ace (highest difficulty) with a decent, well-upgraded car. Like a Buggati Divo or La Voiture Noire. But then you'll sweat to finish even the 'Easy' drag races without grinding.  3. Physics: Funny. If you're looking for a racing game with realistic or good physics, this isn't the one. They've surely made the car handling better with each update, but it still hurts to see a hypercar wobble at 400+ kmph with slight curves.  4. Optimization: I'm not sure how it scored 7/10 on GameDebate for optimization. I have a good GPU. Though it runs smooth most of the time, a crowded street race or a multiplayer with varied ping rates would cause immediate lags. Sometimes even kick players out. Even the processor and the GPU runs hotter during the gameplay as compared to other games of the same scale.  5. PvP: There's no customizability for PvP races. Also, the PvP player base is low and often results in a long waiting time.  If you're a racing freak who loves arcade and don't mind a bit of a funny physics, go get it. You won't regret. If you're into simulators and graphics, stay away. I've been a Forza fan myself (have a good amount of hours spent on the windows store version), but this game is still very fun in what it offers.

Three steps to slowly but surely climbing up the racing leaderboards in the Crew 2: 1. Grind for better parts (Loot) 2. Grind money (to re-roll affixes) 3. Grind for followers (maximal perks)  The Crew 2 is a racing RPG at its best!

I ignored this game for many years because I thought every single event involved a mix of cars, boats, and flying. Oh no, I was very wrong.  Had a lot of fun with this one. I bought the base game on sale for 10 bucks. The season pass isn't necessary as it just adds more cars and a slight discount in the game store, but you don't need it, you just gotta play and earn stuff that way which to me is more fun.   I'm really glad there's actually characters and narratives that kept me interested. A lot of racing games are just go here, do the race, go to the next one, etc etc. But here the story, leveling up, loot and characters made it feel like I was aiming for a goal.   There's a TON of stuff to do. Street racing, hyper car racing, drag, drift, power boats, air races,  rallycross, hovercraft, motocross, touring, demolition derby, and MONSTER TRUCKS!!!! Those were my favorite. It's all arcadey feeling, so you can turn your car in mid air and stuff like that. There's also HUGE JUMPS which are so much fun. Plus there's loads of side activities like taking photos of landmarks, animals, stunts, etc, and escape missions, speed traps to name a few. Not to mention weekly events (called Live Summit) that have leaderboards and rewards are based on how many points you rack up against other players.   On top of all that there's these really cool movie like scenarios called Motorflix where you have to either do events for movies, or smash vehicles like youre in Burnout 3. AND there's treasure map type missions where you get clues and have to find the specific area and take a picture, which when all are completed you'll get a nice reward. All of it is completely optional. You don't have to do every single event in any section to progress. I jumped around a lot. When I got tired of races, I'd jump into some drag races, monster trucks, photo ops, live summit or the motorflix. Just whatever you wanna do.  Speaking of rewards, this game gives them out nicely. Not just cars either. You can get parts, cool visual stuff like neon underglows or colored tire smoke or nitro colors. It's basically a dopamine simulator.   Got all the achievements, completed the live extreme series and did over 70% of street racing, offroad, freestyle, and pro racing events. I also did all three seasons of motorflix and part of season six. There's still a ton of stuff left to do if I wanted as well.  The only stuff I didn't like was that since you can fast travel to any event, there isn't much reason to drive around the world. Kinda wish they would take a Forza Horizon approach and have billboards and fast travel boards scattered around to encourage this, but the way the whole game is set up is still really fun. I wish the game had more steam achievements too since there's so many things to do and unlock in game. Kinda surprised they had em in the first place considering it's a Ubisoft game. But the worst part is it's online all the time, which means when Ubi shuts down the servers the game will be dead, probably. So it's possible the game has an expiration date, unless they let people play it single player.   And let me point out that while the game is called The Crew 2, I basically played almost the entire game by myself. I joined a crew for a little bit and did some stuff, but then I guess I got kicked out but all of my progress was still there so no big deal.

I can't express how deeply unsatisfying the non-physics-based driving feels; it's worse than a cheap arcade motorcycle game. Furthermore, online required (see what happened to The Crew 1), terrible, LONG, extremely frequent cut-scenes, very poor UI decisions (I couldn't even figure out how to exit the game!), FPS and resolution limited, a mandatory anti-cheat driver, and mediocre graphics means that there are far better games out there. The only reason I can see to purchase this game is for its boat racing, but even then, it's boring, in my opinion.  I don't really understand the positive reviews given how terrible driving feels to be honest.

The Crew 2 has got the potential for a good arcade racing game. Unfortunately it's not.   While the graphics look nice and the cars offer very good feedback, the whole setting sucks. The story makes you want to turn of your PC as soon as those ai smart asses, you have to team up with, start talking. Their constant advice makes you want to throw up, run away or punch them in the face. And they keep talking all the time.  Of course you're a rookie driving your way up to stardom by collecting followers. The dream of every six year old.  And of course your path to the top is riddled with obstacles. At least that's something Ubisoft really does well. Especially when this concept forces players to pay real money to overcome the hindrances.  Your main hindrance are cars because you ain't got none. Or should I say almost none. The standard version of The Crew 2 gives you a slow street car, a slow plane and a slow boat. At least this allows you to play some races.   You need to win races to gain followers. Ending games in first, second or third position also grants you upgrades for your vehicle.  Additionally you earn in-game money. In-game money is needed to buy new cars, planes or boats. And that's exactly where Ubisofts sales department steps in. In order to shorten the tedious task of endlessly driving races to win the money necessary to buy cars for different events or higher racing classes, you can simply buy in-game money with real money.   You can also buy the season pass which grants you two new cars every month for one year and an in-game discount when buying new cars. Of course the season pass costs real money.  You also need the best cars in order to compete with other players in multi-player mode. It will take you a lot of racing time winning the necessary in-game money to buy the cars needed to beat the competition. And you also need to upgrade the cars.  No matter what type of car you buy, you always receive the standard edition. So you need to drive races with this car to add upgrades.   There's a lot of work to get the cars you need. And Ubisoft made sure that there are many different vehicles you need.  - Street Race - Drift - Drag Race - Hyper Car - Rally Raid - Moto Cross - Rally Cross - Aerobatics - Jetsprint - Monster Truck - Powerboat - Touring Car - Air Race - Alpha GP  In order to stand a chance in multi-player mode you need to learn the tracks including all shortcuts. Thankfully the multi-player tracks are the same as the single-player races. This gives you the chance to train and memorize routes.  Contrary to The Crew 1 the USA is no longer the star of the game. Although graphics have improved, villages and cities look exchangeable. The unique atmosphere of Chicago, New York, San Francisco or Miami is no longer perceptible in The Crew 2. Even the countryside sometimes looks artificial. Not everywhere, but in some places.   At some locations it seems as if the developers didn't finish designing the landscape. There are areas where bushes and trees seem to be missing and hills are bald.  Free riding is no longer fun. That's because other cars drive closer together. The Crew 1 allowed you to race top speed in the middle of the highway passing cars on both sides. Try that in The Crew 2 and you will constantly crash.  You often find places where the game tells you to take a photo. You'll get an achievement once you took 40 photos in unique places. If you tell the game to mark the spot for the photo nothing is marked. You'll start searching but don't know where to go. There's no mark at all and neither navigation not mini-map can guide you. Then you take a photo and still have 40 photos left to take.  The same applies for extra upgrades. Extra upgrades are scattered all over the US. Once you move close to an upgrade your navigation system starts blinking and pinging. But if you search for the upgrade it's nowhere to be found. At least I can't find them. In 20 hours play time I found a single upgrade. It was a huge shining blue box on a field, twice as big as my car and it could not be missed. But whenever I search for them in a city they are nowhere to be found. Not sure if it's me but it's frustrating. I think it's bugged or again unfinished development.  I could continue listing disadvantages but I guess you get the idea. Steam only allows 8000 words per review and I had to shorten this one.  The Crew 2 is a mess and the games only purpose is to pull money out of your pockets. I assume Ubisoft forced the developers to design the game this way. Market target are kids and youngsters that are likely to pay for better cars. Make it colorful, rise their self-esteem by increasing their number of followers and make them feel important.  Is there something good? Yes.  The developers managed to make drifting very enjoyable and very well controllable, given you picked the right car. I found the Ford Mustang GT Fastback to offer fantastic drift control.  All cars feel different and every car behaves very unique. That's a point the developers really did well. Feedback from cars is great and you can really feel if you're driving a limousine, a muscle car or a beach buggy.  Pros: - beautiful graphics - many races - very good feedback from cars - all cars feel unique - driving in general is fun - very good car engine sounds - you can fine tune your cars in very many ways (if you find the settings) - all cars, boats and planes can be test driven (for one or two minutes) - some upgrades offer special bonuses - photo mode, including filters  Cons: - extremely annoying story and ai team partners - ...that keep talking annoying bullshit and treat you like a child - cities feel artificial and static even if they look beautiful - only random car upgrades - very buggy - even crashes sometimes - distant traffic very often vanishes if you move closer - feels unfinished - every race has an introduction where you have to drive to the start line and some idiot gives annoying advice or talks about other very infuriating nonsense - ...and it happens every time you re-start the race - tries hard to make you pay real money - the game even sells clothes for your avatar - vehicles are very expensive making it an endless grind to buy a hyper-car - limited fun - often hard to find players in multi-player although the game is not that old - multiplayer races are far less fun than in The Crew 1 - free ride is far less fun than in The Crew 1 and often very annoying - zoomed out map of USA is simply black and white and looks far worse than in The Crew 1 - cumbersome, annoying menu navigation - not a single good song on the in-game radio stations. Seriously - not one. Not even in classic. - emphasis on single-player - long start time - no cops - cars given to season pass owners can not be purchased by none season pass owners - even some T-Shirts for your avatar can only be bought by season pass owners - boat races are difficult because you loose a lot of speed when you jump over ramps while the ai somehow doesn't - rubber-band ai - annoying photo challenges - ...and a lot of annoying other challenges - the game does not grant you upgrades or money if you win in a higher difficulty but your car does not have the necessary upgrade class. Even if you actually did win! WTF?! - all player characters are ugly and can't be changed once you picked yours - you only get loot in races if you win - no reason to explore the map independently (unlike in The Crew 1) - drag races are still extremely boring - plane acrobatics are even more boring - monster trucks and hovercrafts are totally unnecessary - I couldn't figure out how to instantly switch between cars, planes and boats - I couldn't figure out how to join a crew

If this game goes on sale for $15 and you have nothing else to play I could recommend this game. The sad part is, this is a good game. It's a lot of fun. But the reason I can't recommend it is because the PVP is completely fucked. The Live Summit is the only way to get exclusive vehicles, but good luck ranking high enough in the live summit to score one of those exclusive vehicles. If you check the leaderboards, its blatantly obvious that the top players (whom you have to compete against in order to win the exclusive rewards) are exploiting. You can literally watch their ghost use these exploits to achieve a higher score, meaning the only way for you to beat them and unlock exclusive vehicles is to take all the fun out of the game and use the exploit yourself. If you just want to play solo, or with friends, I can recommend this game because the driving is fun and the graphics are great. However as a fan of PVP and racing games, I can't recommend this game until the dev team decides to do something about all of the exploiting players that rule the leaderboards. They need to either remove the exploits and wipe the leaderboards, or make it so that you can unlock every vehicle in the game without participating in the live summits. Either fix the PVP, or give us a way to work around it and still enjoy the game.

Games sold as Single Player titles should have offline capabilities. They should not have Always Online features. It is appalling how disconnected the companies are from their clientele.  As long as the product is sold and non-refundable, they are good. If the patch doesn't come out for the game that is being taken down just because Online features and upkeep of the servers are not feasible things for the company, it will clearly show there the interest lies.   People get it, keeping up with server payments and infrastructure is costly and doesn't get cheaper, but if you pull a license from paying customers just like that, I really hope people will take notice and never buy anything from them going forward.   I won't, and will do my best to advise everyone I can to steer clear from companies like Ubisoft and Electronic Arts.   And I really do hope companies that feel that it's an okay thing to do to their customers will implode and close up shop. It would suck for talented people who work on good games, but they are not the ones that profit from their own creations.  Edit: If anything, it would be somewhat of a fun time to pirate games of the said company to enjoy them for free. And without the constant worry that the library I've spent money on will go AWOL because some asshole in a suit made a call. I'm more than happy to pay for games I play, but the sad reality we all worried about for about a decade and a half start to creep in - If it's not Physical, don't buy it. I'm sure there will be more and more precedents like this and the big companies will hide behind "anti-piracy drm" argument with their Always Online bullshit as well.  I guess it's about time we dust off the old consoles and revisit some second-hand marketplaces for games we like.

I'd say this game is worth a try. There’s plenty of racing, though it’s kind of like the towers in Assassin’s Creed or Far Cry—you’re constantly grinding for something.  About that grind: collecting tuning parts (to get bonuses, you need to put together a full set of the same color and type) can be a hassle. Don’t expect to complete a set easily—you’ll likely be replaying the same race multiple times. There are around 200 races in total, each with three difficulty levels. I’ve cleared 88% of the main races and about 51% of the three other categories, and I’m nowhere near completing a full set on any car. But honestly, you don't need a full set. Once you max out your car’s power, you can just blow past the AI ​​opponents and enjoy the view.  And the views here are worth it. The game is gorgeous, and the scale is impressive. You truly feel like you’re driving across an entire country. The map might even be bigger than Euro Truck Simulator's, even with all the DLC. Each state has its own distinct look and vibe, and I loved the variety.  The one downside is that the game kind of forces you to try different modes. I wasn’t really into planes or Off-Road, though the boat races were surprisingly fun. Some modes just feel pointless, like Derby. It’s just cars bouncing around with no real destruction physics. And F1 racing doesn’t really fit either—the arcade physics don’t do it justice, and when you’re driving an F1 car off-road, it’s just weird.  At first, I hated Off-Road races and was ready to skip them. I tried MX, Aerobatics, and Touring Car instead, but that sense of “incomplete” pushed me to finish those 20 Off-Road races, unlock the boss, and complete all the achievements.  Overall, the game’s pretty easy—maybe too easy. To make it more challenging, you’d have to clear everything on the easiest difficulty first, and with a game this big, that can get tiring. I put in 30 hours and only got through half the game. I really enjoyed the hypercars, though; I’d be down for even more long races that last an hour or more. There’s something special about speeding down a wide-open highway, listening to music, and soaking up the graphics.  In short, there’s something for everyone here, so I’d say it’s worth a thumbs-up.

Given my opinions and thoughts on its predecessor, I never thought I would've liked The Crew 2, let alone recommend it. But here I am. It's not a 100% recommendation, the game sure does have its flaws but for the price I paid during this sale, it's well worth it and deserves praise. And considering how much this game tries to get as close as possible to its competitor Forza Horizon, a comparison between the two games is as natural as it is mandatory. Let's examine its strengths:  Map: it's HUGE. I really mean it. It's huge unlike any other map you have seen in any other racing game. Looking at Forza Horizon's maps makes them look like they're the size of an ant. And unlike in The Crew 1, I get a feeling of traveling in the middle of nowhere much less frequently. Environments are diverse and there is more attention to details. Many opportunities for offroad. It really gives you a sense of freedom when exploring. Big yes.  Loading times: ... loading times? Never heard of that. Seamlessly teleport around the map and change vehichles on the fly. No waiting.  Content: cars? Let's be honest, that's the main reason we play this game for, right? Not just street-legal cars, but also offroad trucks and buggies, rallycross cars, and hypercars. But we ain't got only that. We have boats, planes and hovercrafts at our disposal as well. Which of course are a nice addition, but we're most likely going to spend most of our time in our beloved 4-wheel vehichles (2 wheel if you're into bikes, we got that too). And the game's car park is vast enough as well. Forza by contrast only offers cars... but a much wider selection of them.  Map activities: unlike in The Crew 1, these are not mandatory to grind in order to upgrade your car (which can take a serious amount of time if you're extremely unlycky), but there is only a goal to beat. That's it.  Sound: they're pretty good. That's judging from the Alfa Romeo Giulia, which sounds exactly like its real life counterpart, so I assume other sounds should be faithful to what they're supposed to reproduce.  Car performance upgrades: it's not good but it's still a great improvement from the previous game. Anytime you complete an event, you're guaranteed to receive a car part that's better than those already installed in your cars. And all performance parts are shareable across all vehichles in the same category, without being bound to the specific vehichle you obtained them with. You can potentially use a single high leveled car to obtain performance parts to upgrade all other similar vehichles almost instantly. Still not as good as just buying them with your own money but I'm not complaining...  Soundtrack: I can't describe how much more enjoyable this is compared to The Crew 1. I can finally play more than the only one decent song in the entire songlist.  Story: glad they ditched the story element. The plot in The Crew 1 was poor to say the least and I'd much rather have a generic motorsport event as a context than that. Annnnd this is where it's clear that this game is trying to get close to Forza Horizon. Win, progress across the various rounds of said generic competition, become the champion.  Now, to the "meh" parts:  Graphics: they're all but impressive. In fact it looks quite like The Crew 1. Except it even goes backwards. I'd like to know who thought it would be a good idea not to enable users to switch TAA off. The result is that the game looks like it's being run on console, extremely blurry at 1080p, like it was rendered at a lower resolution. While it can be disabled in a settings file, it breaks effects that rely on it, such as reflections. But hey, at least it will look crisp. Overall geometry detail is also mediocre. Oh, and also forced 60 FPS cap. No contest compared to Forza.  AI and difficulty: I'm getting Mario Kart flashbacks.The rubberbanding is just insane. And the difficulty balance across the events is way off. You will see opponents in front of you slowing down to let you pass only to see the same opponents zoom at godlike speeds past you once you're in front. And instead, in the RAID events, the prerecorded ghost is easy to beat, letting me win with a comfortable 40 seconds gap on average using a car with the recommended performance rating for the event.  Physics: better than the previous entry. Cars are still going to be prone to drifting and handbrake will still be useless (sending your car into an almost full stop the moment you press it and steer afterwards) but the driving experience remains overall enjoyable once you get used to it. It just... doesn't feel as natural as Forza.  Disciplines: this games does so many things at once and as a results doesn't shine in anything in particular. But being it arcade-oriented and given what I paid for it, it's not too much of a downside. It still includes and offers way more variety compared to its competitors.  Always-online: as far as I can tell, there is not too much focus on the online element... so why force us to be connected at all times? Folks with unstable internet connections such as myself don't like this you know.  In conclusion: give it a try. Not at a full price, though, or you risk feeling severely disappointed. In fact, I'd much rather pay full price on Forza than this. But overall... it's fun.

Pros: 1. Various race types. Air/Land/Water all in one. 2. Good Car selections.  Cons: 1. Bad controls for cars. Yes, it is arcade, not supposed to be realistic, but I don't really think it should feel like your tires is not sticking to the road. 2. Confusing key mappings. It does not tell you the controls when you got thrown into your first race/demo. The pause menu is not ESC but F10. You cannot have completely separate key binding for vehicles and airplanes. 3. Graphics is all right but could be a lot better. But why there is still a 60-FPS frame limiter? 4. Not really better than The Crew 1, if not worse.  Final Thoughts: If you want to buy this mainly because of car racing, there are many more options better than this one. NFS series for arcade, Forza Horizon for semi-arcade, Assetto Corsa/Project Car 2/Forza Motorsport for simulation side.  P.S. Forza Horizon 4 is coming October, might as well just wait for that one.

[h1] Drive like you stole it! [/h1] The Crew 2 is an open-world racing game developed by Ivory Tower and published by Ubisoft. It was released in 2018 and is a sequel to the original The Crew game. The game allows players to explore a vast open-world recreation of the United States, race against other players online, and collect a variety of vehicles, including cars, boats, planes, and motorcycles.  [h2] Pros and cons [/h2] [table] [tr] [th] 🟩 Positives [/th] [th] 🟥 Negatives [/th] [/tr] [tr] 	[td] - Expansive open-world with a variety of environments to explore  - Impressive level of vehicle customisation  - Wide range of vehicles to collect, including rare and unique ones  - Well-designed vehicle models with realistic handling  - Weekly events and challenges provide a sense of progression and competition  - Impressive graphics and sound design 	[/td] 	[td] - Grindy nature of the game may be off-putting for some players  - Limited storyline and lack of compelling characters  - Some "vanities" can only be obtained through real money or live summits  - Multiplayer PvP mode is limited to simple point-to-point races  - Some bugs and issues with the game, though most have been addressed through updates and patches. 	[/td] [/tr] [/table]	  [h2] Gameplay [/h2] The Crew 2's gameplay is enjoyable and immersive, with a strong emphasis on exploration and racing. The game's expansive open-world allows players to explore various environments, from bustling cities to scenic countryside landscapes. The game's attention to detail is impressive, with realistic handling of the different vehicles and a wide range of customisation options.  [h3] Events [/h3] The game's "live summits" events are weekly events where players can win vanity items or time-limited cars. However, some players may struggle to win the top prize without first obtaining cars and parts that give them an advantage. The game's multiplayer PvP mode is a simple race from point A to point B.  [h2] Vehicles [/h2] The game offers rare, unique vehicles not usually found in other racing games. The game's vehicle models are well-designed, and the level of customisation is impressive, allowing players to almost widebody every car. However, some of the game's "vanities" can only be obtained through real money or live summits, which may be off-putting for some players.  [h2] Story [/h2] The game's story is minimal, with no clear protagonist or antagonist, and the game focuses more on exploration and racing than storytelling. However, the game's open-world and the various challenges and events provide a sense of progression.  [h2] Graphics and Sound [/h2] The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed vehicle models and environments that look and feel realistic. The game's sound design is also noteworthy, with diverse sound effects adding to the immersive experience.  [h2] Conclusion [/h2] Overall, The Crew 2 is an enjoyable and immersive racing game that offers a vast open-world, a wide range of vehicles, and various events to compete in. The game's attention to detail is impressive, and the vehicle models are well-designed with realistic handling. However, some players may find the game's grindy nature and lack of a compelling story mode to be a turnoff. Nevertheless, The Crew 2 is still a game worth playing for racing fans and those who enjoy exploring and customising their vehicles.

I tried this game when it was free for a weekend, and decided to buy it. It is a very relaxing racing game which I play after office hours.  Positives: - There is a lot of content, and not the usual boring and filler material. So many types of races, including destruction derby, bike races and boats will keep you busy. - It is easy to upgrade cars, you get a lot of materials to upgrade. Live Summit changes every week and provides good rewards so leveling up is easy. - This game has one of the best ways to display the map that I have seen in a racing game.  - On Normal level, it is an easy game, so I play the race on normal and win, then try it on hard (and win again most of the time).   Negatives:  - Ubisoft - In a lot of races, you race against a ghost and there are no other drivers. - Soundtrack is mediocre. Racing games like NFS and Forza have one of the best soundtracks, something you enjoy while driving, but not here. Very okish.  - Graphics are good, but at some places, houses look like boxes.  - Online component is dead.  I also find the plane controls pathetic, although I am not sure if others feel this too.  Overall, it is worth the money. Get the gold edition, so that you have a headstart with extra cars and content.

I have finished all of the achievements before writing this review.  Multiplayer arcade race game where you race others with cars, bikes, boats and planes with a full controller support. Characters and story are forgettable, the gameplay though is very fun. If you are looking for realism, this is not a place for you. No police, traffic light changes every 2 sec, no vehicle damage (just scratches), drag cars can reach the speed of almost 700kmh (434mph), if you put side exhaust you will still have rear one.  The game loads once, and you are ready to go! The fast restarts, smooth vehicle swap, travel to challenges etc. Amazing car details and they sound awesome (except motorcycles). Radio offers a variety of different stations so every person can find something for them to listen (and I did not know about it because of a lack of tutorial and guidance in this game). Nevertheless, the world feels empty and lacks some serious gameplay. There is almost no reason to explore the in-game world apart from taking photo opportunities. There are no collectables, few skill games and limitless highlights with top speed, high jump and long drift.   Lots of vehicles, various race types, decent co-op gameplay BUT no PvP. The Crew is all about the PvP and it is not here at launch. "The Crew 2" has many of the same cars but in different categories, so if you buy a car in a Street Race category, you can use it for that only compared to the first game.  You can but a Ford Mustang as a Street, Drift, Drag, Track and Monster Truck. And here comes the currency problem. I hate games with microtransactions, but at least here you can play without the urge to spend some real cash. Although the prices are ridiculously high, it is not that hard to grind it out. Performance parts will come as a loot for finishing a race (green, blue, epic and I think legendary will be added with later updates), and it will take a long time to max out a single car because you can get parts with lower performance than what you have. Rare and Epic parts will have 1 and 2 additional modifiers respectively and you can use it to boost your gameplay in many ways.  Car customisation is pretty good but it is limited to the Street Racers Family (Cars with yellow icon) and Monster Trucks. For other classes, you can only change their wheels! You can create your own livery or download one of the popular ones and at least this feature is for all of them.  The game leaves a huge levelling potential (up to 9999) but to be honest there is no reason to do so, because at 600 is your last car reward, and every 10 levels from that point are just epic loot.  Races may vary from short ones up to 40min long with a "rubber-banding" difficulty which can be brutal since you will drive at your limits and AI will sometimes push you around and frustrate the hell out of you.  What is a "Rubber Banding"? - Pushes them towards you if you are far from them and lowers their speed if you are too far behind. So, if you are driving at your and car's limit, the AI (especially 2nd place) will go into hyperspeed to catch up with you. They are not that generous if you fall behind but the AI will still slow down.  Now, I want to speak of things that frustrated me the most - lack of tutorials and a car reset. The game lacks tutorial in some cases! There are so many questions and no clear explanation or indication on how to do some stuff: how to shift a drag car, where is the mailbox when to use two different modes of boats etc. The last one will be verbally explained by one of the characters but if you miss it...   Now, the car resets... It takes 2 FULL seconds to put it back on track and sometimes it will put you WAY back in the race and if you happened to make a mistake in a 40 min long race, you are royally screwed. I was 1st and one small mistake (because the game doesn't show you the raceway like it should) + reset made me the last place with a 10 sec gap to 7th place. I saved the run and finished first but I was at 30% of the race when that happened.  Although I would still recommend this game but not for a full price unless everything I have said above is fine for you. As they did with "The Crew" they will add more content in here and it will feel much better to play it but until then, wait for a sale. I've seen a lot of mixed reviews, I recommend it although it isn't a perfect game.  Some people seem to complain about landmarks and graphics. I find the graphics are great, and i couldn't care less about landmarks.  The MOST important thing to keep in mind, this is an ARCADE STYLE racing game. Not a simulator. If you wanted hyper realism then look elsewhere.  - Great vehicle selection - Good controls - Extensive Customization (you can get lost in it for hours) - Reward vehicles from the previous game - Playing with friends - Larger map area - Larger selection of events to do - More content to come  Here are some flaws (some major)  - Voice acting is ridiculous. No adults speak like these do. - WHERES THE MULTIPLAYER RACES?! (I know, they said they come in December, but most of us bought the game for the MP experience) - Not enough physical damage to vehicles (they seem to have dropped the "repair" feature) - Transition from car to boat to plane could have been slightly smoother    Everyone has a different opinion on the game. I'm just being honest. In terms of what I expected out of the game, I got exactly what I wanted... minus the delayed PVP/Multiplayer Racing.  I recommend the game, as long as players remember this is an ARCADE STYLE racing game, and not a simulation.

TL;DR - Ok, it is not that I hate this game, but I just don't recommend it.  For what it is worth, I have fun playing, the customization is nice and the driving feels (for the most part) good. What I have the most issue with is the glitches, minor inconveniences to game breakers. At the time of posting this review, the game literally does not start despite my efforts to get it to do run beyond the title screen. There is also a rather large amount of questionable choices in regards to what you can just blow through and what will crash your vehicle. My last real complaint is the lack of police chases that were present in the first game, while it doesn't exactly fit the "story," it would have been nice to have been included for more incentive to explore and drive around.  Fortunately there is a lot I do like about the game. The car selection is very nice and while I am not the biggest fan of the boat/plane additions, I could see some enjoying the features thoroughly. I also like the Summit activities, which once a week update and always give me something to come back to (while it may be just recycling races from the base game). I also never have felt a need to resort to microtransactions.   In conclusion, I do like this game, after all, there is a reason I have dumped 150+ hours into it, but if you are on the fence, I can only recommend it on a decent sale. Otherwise, Steam offers some NFS games now that may better suit what you may be looking for. Cool game, but a bit lackluster.

The actions of the game take place in the United States of America, during the game you will have where to turn around, drift, drag, ring races, as well as races all over the map, there will be no borders in front of you. ... You can buy a car of any level, the first good car will not be long in coming. Farming money in the game happens pretty quickly, but it's no less interesting from it. The map shows major cities in the States, as well as their attractions. Simply stunning graphics, effects of water, mud, rain, sun, clouds. Also, during the game you will visit the winter season, the physics of the car will change quite noticeably, which cannot but rejoice. But there are also disadvantages, your car in the game is not titanium, a small tree, like in Forza, will not be able to knock down, when it collides with a stone, it will most likely not stop it, but throw it up. You will be able to publish your work on the official website of the game.  The game also has character customization, leveling up skills, making a model out of furniture to make everyone envy you.  In conclusion, I want to say that it is a very rich game, its advantages overlap all the disadvantages, many updates have been made to the game, as well as a battle pass, if you are not sure about buying the game, then look at its reviews on the Internet. Ok, gonna keep this short. Don't buy this game.  With Forza Horizon 4 just around the corner, I'd recommend waiting for that.  This game has a lot of cool ideas and neat features, but is flawed in two MAJOR ways.  1. No person that likes customizing cars wants to get their parts from random loot at the end of races. That's just cringeworthy.  2. The physics are god awful. Turning feels lazy, there is no sense of speed, everything seems to float like GTA IV, and a lot of the control is handled by assists that dont turn off. There ends up being no sense of skill involved in driving.  What the hell good is a racing game about building and racing cars, when the building is largely out of your control, and the driving is completely unsatisfying?   Also, as a nitpick, the game is capped at 60fps, and the car models are pretty damn poor compared to Forza. The lighting model in this game is awesome, thats about it.

If you like racing game, enormous map with all sorts of diversity, many cars with many customisation and regular new events, then this game is definitely for you. Be a fearless racer or just fun chill driver, this game offers me so many things.
